title: 105_hr4098
content: The conveyance of Two Harbors Lighthouse in Minnesota is discussed in Section 1. The Commandant of the Coast Guard may convey the Coast Guard Light Station Two Harbors in Minnesota to the Lake County Historical Society. Any historical artifacts on the property will remain the personal property of the United States. Any conveyance of real property under this section shall be made without payment of consideration and subject to terms and conditions to protect the interests of the United States, including reservation of easements. The conveyance must also ensure that any active aid to navigation on the property remains the personal property of the United States. The Lake County Historical Society must not interfere with any aid to navigation on the property without permission from the Commandant. The United States reserves the right to operate, maintain, and make changes to any aid to navigation on the conveyed real property for navigational purposes. The Lake County Historical Society is not obligated to maintain any aid to navigation on the conveyed property. They must maintain the property according to the National Historic Preservation Act and at their own cost. The conveyance of real property under this section requires proper maintenance and reverts to the United States if not used for maritime history preservation. The real property conveyed must be maintained for aids to navigation or in accordance with the National Historic Preservation Act. If needed for national security, the Commandant must provide notice to the Lake County Historical Society at least 30 days before reversion. The term "Lake County Historical Society" refers to a nonprofit corporation in Minnesota dedicated to preserving historical lighthouse equipment for navigation purposes.
